description: The Nasdaq Composite peaked, signaling the end of the late-1990s tech-driven equity boom. The subsequent market downturn contributed to reduced household wealth and tightened credit availability, slowing demand for housing nationwide.

In response to early signs of economic slowdown, the Fed began a series of interest-rate cuts. Lower borrowing costs boosted mortgage demand and helped sustain home‐price appreciation through the early 2000s.
By December 2007, rising mortgage delinquencies in subprime loans signaled a downturn in the housing market. Home‐price growth stalled and began to decline as credit tightened.
The collapse of Lehman intensified the 2008 financial crisis. Credit markets froze, home‐price declines accelerated, and nationwide housing values fell sharply over the next 18 months.

Home‐price indices (e.g., Case-Shiller) reached their trough. Federal actions—such as the Home Affordable Modification Program (HAMP) and the Fed’s zero‐rate policy—laid groundwork for a gradual recovery.
By mid-2012, major home‐price indices posted year‐over‐year gains as the Fed’s QE2/QE3 programs, improving labor markets, and renewed consumer confidence helped jump-start the housing recovery.

The U.S. declared a national emergency. The Federal Reserve cut rates to near zero and launched additional quantitative easing. Combined with remote‐work flexibility, housing demand and prices surged through 2021 into early 2022.

To combat rising inflation, the Fed raised the federal funds rate from 0%–0.25% to 0.25%–0.50%. Mortgage rates climbed sharply, curbing affordability and triggering a slowdown (and modest decline) in home‐price growth beginning spring 2022.
After successive rate hikes, 30-year fixed mortgage rates hovered above 7%. Buyer demand weakened further, and home‐price appreciation cooled to near‐flat in many markets.
Following a period of rate‐hike cycles, the Fed paused. With borrowing costs steady, home‐price growth began to stabilize, signaling a new phase of market equilibrium.
